It depends a little bit on how much decision making is outsourced

If it is "I don't pay attention to tax laws, I just pay my advisor to sort it out," which I suspect is often the case for HNWIs then behavioral responses are going to be highly correlated across clientele of a given agency

Londoners - who sleep in a hotbed of dirty money - care a lot less about money laundering

Source: www.ukanticorruptioncoalition.org/work/report-...
If using administrative data, it would be better to cluster on the submitter ID - if tax advisor

Thought: most papers on the impact of behavioral effects of tax policy changes among those at the top of the distribution are reporting the wrong standard errors, because individuals are probably using a much smaller (unobserved) set of tax advisors & thus are not independent observations

Ah yes - I meant exclusively tampering of the numbers, rather than projects/project conditions. A lot of people in the degrowth movement seem to think that the WB's choice of its main poverty line is done intentionally to look like growth has been more successful at pushing people out of poverty
A competent leadership would be a bulwark against this kind of pressure. All it does is damage the institution.

Many WB critics have this view that it fiddles the numbers in order to serve some grand pro-market / progress narrative The sad reality is that most of the unreasonable political pressure / tampering comes from really *big* client countries who don't like looking bad

Ah sorry - I think I misinterpreted the figure: "highest possible life expectancy" = "what is the highest expectancy I would face if I moved to the part of the world that had the highest" not "what is the maximum possible lifespan"

My first post here is going to be this cool new chart from @@182468! It shows which country had the highest female life expectancy in each year.

The horizontal lines show predictions of 'maximum life expectancy' that could be achieved.

Predictions have been broken again and again!

Where do most of these predictions come from? They seem indifferent to historical examples (e.g. Elizabeth I died at age 69 in 1603.... so why would anyone claim that the maximum life expectancy for women was lower... and why would anyone take that claim seriously, even back then?)
So much of good data work is just repeatedly stopping, looking at the results of what you've done so far and asking yourself "does this make sense?" over and over and over and over again
But not with n=35

Cyprus is not yet on the FATF's assessment calendar. 

A new review needs to be prioritized, given all that has come to light in the Cyprus confidential leaks

www.icij.org/investigatio...

Some suggestions: 

* Officials form countries that represent a serious money laundering threat to the country being reviewed *should not be part of the review process*

* The FATF desperately needs a review process that actually considers and prioritizes the threats being faced

Their penultimate follow up review was managed in part by representatives from Russia, the very state that has been using Cyprus 

That review was released less than a month before the invasion of Ukraine

MONEYVAL's (the regional FATF body) follow-up review of Cyprus, conducted *after* the invasion of Ukraine, makes zero mention of Russia, barely any mention of sanctions or politically-exposed persons, and instead is obsessed with the potential abuse of non-profits

www.fatf-gafi.org/content/dam/...

As per the latest FATF assessments, Cyprus scored about the same or *better* as the median European country on the ratings of how effective its measures of fighting financial crime were

The same Cyprus that is a well known conduit country for facilitating sanctions evasion by Russian oligarchs

Policy idea:

Don't pre-announce sanctions 

Source: www.theguardian.com/business/202...
